revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=April 2011}} {{cleanup|date=May 2010}} }}
'''Medical education in Panama''' is principally offered and developed by accredited and government recognized [[medical school]]s in the country. There are 5 medical schools in [[Panama]], typically offering the Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery degrees. In Panama medical programs are divided into two types: [[undergraduate]] entry and [[Graduate student|graduate]] entry.
==Entrance== '''Undergraduate''' entry degrees are typically 6 years in duration and commonly tend to draw students entering directly from [[high school]]; while '''graduate''' entry degrees are typically 4 years in length, and draw a [[university]] graduate with a current 4 years [[Bachelor's degree]] required for entry. These entries provide the medical programs with a variety in the age range and academic backgrounds of the participants.
It is important to note, however, that the graduate entry program still confers a Bachelor’s degree in [[Medicine]]; that although it is a graduate entry program, it does not confer a [[postgraduate degree]] in itself.
==Requirements== In order to practice medicine in the Republic, or enter a residency program in Panama it is required to be Panamenian citizen.
Other requirements include: *First year rotatory [[Internship]] Qualified medical practitioners must successfully undertake and complete one year of supervised practice, generally known as an internship. Internship is undertaken in [[hospital]] positions accredited for this purpose. *2 year rural Internship Upon successful conclusion of the first intern year, doctors are required to undertake and complete a second year of internship at an assigned government health institution. Once this requirement is fulfilled the [[medical practitioner]]s qualify for a full registration in the Medical Board and are [[medical license|licensed]] to engage in independent medical practice in Panama
==Medical Universities==
Universities with '''undergraduate''' entry medical programs only:
*[[Universidad de Panama]] <ref>http://www.up.ac.pa/PortalUp/index.aspx</ref> *[[Columbus University (Panama)|Columbus University]] <ref>http://www.columbus.edu/</ref> *[[Universidad Latina de Panama]] *[[Universidad Latinoamericana de Ciencia y Tecnología]] ULACIT <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ulacit.ac.pa/cienciasdelasalud/?p=oferta |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121221123127/http://www.ulacit.ac.pa/cienciasdelasalud/?p=oferta |archivedate=2012-12-21 |df= }}</ref> *[[Universidad Autónoma de Chiriquí]] UNACHI, The only one university, outside of Panama City, which offers a complete medical program. This university is located in David, Chiriqui.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unachi.ac.pa/fmedicina/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213195041/http://unachi.ac.pa/fmedicina/ |archivedate=2013-12-13 |df= }}</ref>
Universities with '''graduate''' entry medical programs only:
*[[International School of Medical Sciences]] ISMS <ref>http://isms.edu.pa/</ref>
All the graduate entry programs share a similar application process at this time and comparable to the requirements in the United States. Candidates are first required to have a Premedical Degree in an approved University. A 4 year Bachelor’s degree is required.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.up.ac.pa/ftp/f_medicina/Educ.Medica%20Cont/EDUCACION%20MEDICA%20CONTINUA.PDF *https://web.archive.org/web/20110716162316/http://www.sumaclick.com/owens/relacion-de-la-educacion-medica-de-posgrado-y-la-planificacion-nacional-de-salud-en-america-latina-3/ *http://apmf.wordpress.com/2007/06/14/la-medicina-familiar-en-panama/ *http://www.gacetaoficial.gob.pa/pdfTemp/26105/11898.pdf *http://www.coneaupa.edu.pa/page_ley30{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Medical Education In Panama}} [[Category:Education in Panama]] [[Category:Health in Panama]]

{{Infobox school |name = Monastic Secondary English Boarding School |native_name = गुरुकुल |logo = Monasticbody-4.gif |image = Monastic_Logo1.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Seal of Monastic Higher Secondary English Boarding School |motto = '''Quality Education for Quality Life''' |location= Bhanu Chowk, [[Janakpurdham]] (lower secondary), Dhanusha Path Ward No.1, [[Janakpurdham]] (higher secondary) |country =[[Nepal]] |coordinates = {{coord|26|44|N|85|55|E|display=inline,title}} |type= [[Private boarding school]] [[coeducational]]<ref name="test">[http://202.70.77.75/flash/districtreport/report.php?d=17&v=048&s=170480080&y=2065&r=1&t&st=1-10 Official report of the Government of nepal] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140124154956/http://202.70.77.75/flash/districtreport/report.php?d=17&v=048&s=170480080&y=2065&r=1&t&st=1-10 |date=2014-01-24 }}, Department of Education.</ref> |established = December 29, 1986 |opened = 1986 |founder = Late Dr. Mithlesh Sah |district = Dhanusha |principal = Dr. Sonali Kumari Shah |grades = [[Pre-school playgroup|Playgroup]] to [[10+2|12]] |athletics =Cricket,Football,Basketball,Volleyball,chess,Carrom board |affiliations = [http://www.neb.gov.np/ ''NEB (formerly SEB)''] |website= [http://www.monastic.edu.np/ ''Monastic''] https://m.facebook.com/jaimonastic/
|logo_size = 200px |principal1 = Mrs.Veena Devi Sah (lower secondary), Dr. Sonu Kumar (higher secondary) |principal_label1= Other Principals |students = 3000 (approx) |free_label = Magazine |free_text = ''"Gurukul"'' |colors = [[Dark blue (color)|Dark Blue]] {{Color box|#342D7E}} }} '''Monastic Higher Secondary English Boarding School''' ({{lang-ne|मोनस्टिक उ. मा. बी. जनकपुर}}), (usually known simply as '''Monastic School''') is a private [[boarding school]] in [[Janakpur]]dham, [[Dhanusa District]], south-east [[Nepal]]. It was established in 1986 at a rented house at [[Bhanu Chowk]], where it remained for seven years before expanding to a second location on Dhanusha Path, in the south of the town. Founded by Dr. Mithilesh Shah, it was named ''Monastic'' after the Sanskrit word of [[Gurukul|गुरुकुल]], ''gurukul'', which is a type of school in [[India]], residential in nature, with ''[[shishya]]s'' living in proximity to the [[guru]], often within the same house.<ref>{{cite book | last=Cheong Cheng | first=Cheong Cheng Yin | editors=Tung Tsui Kwok Tung Tsui, Wai Chow King Wai Chow, Magdalena Mo Ching Mok | year=2002| title=Subject Teaching and Teacher Education in the New Century: Research and Innovation | publisher=Springer | location=| isbn =962-949-060-9 | page=194}}</ref> It does not follow the [[guru-shishya tradition]] (''[[parampara]]''), and is a "normal" residential school.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.monastic.edu.np | title=Official website of Monastic School. | publisher=Monastic School | accessdate=July 1, 2012}}</ref>
There are 3000 students in the school aged 5 to 18; the lower school, the middle school and the higher school. All are co-educational and has equal numbers of girls and boys. The first headmaster was [[Doctor of Medicine|Dr.]] Mithilesh Sah, who has occupied the post since the establishment of the school, the first and only headmaster of the school.
Monastic pupils compulsorily take a district level qualification exam in [[grade eight]] and another important test, the [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|School Leaving Certificate level]] ( equivalent to GCSE) tests in [[grade ten]] (aged 15–16), which earns them a [[matriculation]] [[academic degree|degree]] and then, like all the other SLC graduates in Nepal, they have a range of choices where they choose either the state funded [[10+2|10+2 level]] to continue their education in Monastic or any other higher secondary school in Nepal, or the British [[A-level]]s in the sixth form, offered by [[UCLES]] in Nepal, or the [[International Baccalaureate]].<ref>{{cite newsgroup | url=http://teenz.com.np/article/magazine/after-the-iron-gate.html | title=After the Iron Gate | accessdate=July 1, 2012 | author=Basnyat, Bonita S | newsgroup=teenz.com.np}}</ref> The majority of students go on to higher education following the completion of their SLC at the end of [[Year Thirteen]] (aged 17–18).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.wavemag.com.np/issue/article3495.html | title=Leveling with ‘A’ levels | work=Interview and Article | date=May 2010 | agency=Wave | accessdate=July 1, 2012}}</ref>
In 2006, the school was upgraded to [[10+2|higher secondary school]],<ref name="HSEB Affiliation">{{Cite web |url=http://www.hseb.edu.np/content/docs/allaff068.pdf |title=Affiliation Of Higher Secondary Education Board |format=PDF |publisher=The Higher Secondary Education Board, Nepal |accessdate=1 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326081003/http://www.hseb.edu.np/content/docs/allaff068.pdf |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> which means it offers additional subjects related to [[science]], [[management]] and [[arts]] and [[education]].<ref>{{cite press_release | url=http://www.hseb.edu.np/content/curriculum.php | title=Curicullam of HSEB | publisher=Higher Secondary Education Board, Nepal. | accessdate=July 1, 2012}}</ref>
== Overview == Monastic School is a full-fledged English Medium School, ultimately upgraded to [[10+2]] Science, Commerce, Arts and Education.<ref name="test2">[http://www.hseb.edu.np/content/docs/allaff068.pdf HSEB Schools in Nepal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326081003/http://www.hseb.edu.np/content/docs/allaff068.pdf |date=2012-03-26 }}, HSEB,Nepal.</ref> This school was founded by Dr. Mithlesh Kumar Sah in 1985. Monastic School has three branches, namely the [[Lower secondary school|lower secondary]], [[Secondary school|secondary]] and [[higher secondary]] branches, and they are under different supervisions. Most of its affairs are controlled by the founder principal. The school is renowned locally because of its regular good results at the annual [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|SLC]] examinations, and thus has managed to maintain a distinctive place among the [[Popular culture|locals]].<ref name="test10">[http://www.nepalhomepage.com/yellowpages/yellowpages.php?ycatid=957&page=15], Yellow Pages Nepal</ref>
The [[school]] provides [[Boarding school|boarding]] facilities for its students, and runs local transportation services for the students from the outer parts of the [[Janakpur]] city.
== Academics == Monastic School operates two courses of study <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Monasticbody 2.jpg|thumb|Students of Class [[10+2|12]] (2003)along with the teachers]] -->* [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|School Leaving Certificate level]] (a nationwide curriculum up to class 10 prescribed by the [[Department of Education (Nepal)|Department of Education]] of Nepal.<ref name="test" /> * [[10+2|10+2 level]] (Higher Secondary Education Board of Nepal, equivalent alternative to [[A Level|A-levels]]).<ref name="test2" /> The school has had 17 successful batches of [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|SLC]] graduates since 1993, but the college has not lived up to the performance levels of the [[school]].
== Extra curricular activities == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Monasticbody 3.jpg|thumb|Students playing [[Badminton]] in a school competition]] --> The school holds [[Extra curricular|extra-curricular]] activities and training sessions for [[personality development]], most of which include [[Cricket|cricket matches]], quite popular game in that part of the [[Cricket in Nepal|world]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://globalcricket.wordpress.com/2008/01/21/cricket-in-nepal/|title=Cricket in Nepal|date=2008-01-21|website=Global Cricket|access-date=2016-12-17}}</ref> along with some [[Indoor games and sports|indoor games.]] [[Singing]] and [[dancing]] is a common activity and most of the dances are of local [[Mithila (ancient)|mithila]]nchal origin. In the process, the local culture is also practiced.
== Affiliation with Lions Club == Monastic School has established a very belonging relationship with the [[Lions Clubs International|Leo Club of Nepal]]<ref name="test6">{{cite web |url=http://www.leoclubnepal.org.np/member%20clubs.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111083853/http://www.leoclubnepal.org.np/member%20clubs.html |archivedate=2011-11-11 |df= }}, Leo club members list</ref> mainly due to the involvement of [[Sports trainer|sports teacher]] Mr. Birendra Karna and the principal. Both of them are senior regional [[Lions Clubs International|Lions Club members]].<ref name="test8">{{cite web |url=http://www.leoclubnepal.org.np/district%20officers.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111083822/http://www.leoclubnepal.org.np/district%20officers.html |archivedate=2011-11-11 |df= }}, Leo club District officers of Nepal</ref>
The students are found actively participating in the events organized by the local [[Leo clubs]], which mostly includes [[blood donation]], and [[volunteering]] camps.
== Student Quality Circle == Since its inception in Nepal, the [[Quality circle|SQC, Nepal]] has found an active member in Monastic School. It is an active member and the local monitoring body for the [[Quality circle|organization]] as a teacher serving as the regional officer for SQC members in Nepal the organisation QUEST, [[Nepal]].<ref name="test15">[http://www.stx.edu.np/sqc/Members.html stx.edu.np] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930202619/http://www.stx.edu.np/sqc/Members.html |date=2011-09-30 }}</ref>
==Notable alumni== In 2005 a former student of Monastic, Diwaker Jha was awarded RONAST Science and Technology Academy Award for building Zenith, a robot with machine vision and speech coordinated with a simulated display of behavior.<ref name="test20">[http://www.wavemag.com.np/issue/article1941.html Wavemag.com.np] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928235614/http://www.wavemag.com.np/issue/article1941.html |date=2011-09-28 }}</ref><ref name="test22">[http://www.orbitedu.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=20&Itemid=8 OrbitEdu.com]</ref>
== Popularity == Monastic School has [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] and [[Google Plus]] accounts in its name, which are administered by some former students.<ref>http://www.facebook.com/jaimonastic Facebook</ref><ref>https://twitter.com/JaiMonastic Twitter</ref><ref>http://sites.google.com/site/monastichsebschooljanakpur/ Google Plus</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Monastic HSEB, Janakpur}} *{{Official website|http://www.monastic.edu.np}} *{{facebook|Jaimonastic}} *{{twitter|Jaimonastic}}

The '''National Quality Standard''' (or '''NQS''') is the benchmark for the quality of [[Early Childhood Education]] & Care in [[Australia]] (part of the [[National Quality Framework]] (NQF)).<ref name=NQS>{{cite web|title=The National Quality Standard|url=http://www.deewr.gov.au/Earlychildhood/Policy_agenda/quality/documents/nqstandardchildedu.pdf|publisher=Council of Australian Governments|accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Guide to the National Quality Standard|url=http://files.acecqa.gov.au/files/National-Quality-Framework-Resources-Kit/NQF03-Guide-to-NQS-130902.pdf|website=acecqa.gov.au|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref>
== Aim == The National Quality Standard aims to promote: * the [[Child protection|safety]], [[Pediatric nursing|health]] and wellbeing of children * a focus on achieving outcomes for children through high-quality educational programs * families’ understanding of what distinguishes a quality service.<ref name=aim>{{cite web|title=National Quality Framework for Early Childhood Education & Care|url=http://www.deewr.gov.au/Earlychildhood/Policy_Agenda/Quality/Pages/home.aspx|publisher=Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations|accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref>
== Quality Areas == The National Quality Standard (NQS) is a key aspect of the [[National Quality Framework|NQF]]. The NQS consists of seven quality areas, each containing standards and elements, that children's education and care services are assessed and rated against.
The seven quality areas covered by the National Quality Standard are:
* Educational program and practice * Children’s health and safety * Physical environment * Staffing arrangements * Relationships with children * Collaborative partnerships with families and communities * Leadership and service management<ref>{{cite web|title=Guide to the National Quality Standard|url=http://files.acecqa.gov.au/files/National-Quality-Framework-Resources-Kit/NQF03-Guide-to-NQS-130902.pdf|website=www.acecqa.gov.au|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ACECQA - NQS Quality Areas|url=http://www.acecqa.gov.au/Quality-Areas|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Early Years Learning Framework]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.acecqa.gov.au/ Australian Children's Education and Care Quality Authority] *[http://files.acecqa.gov.au/files/National-Quality-Framework-Resources-Kit/NQF03-Guide-to-NQS-130902.pdf Guide to the National Quality Standard] *[http://www.earlychildhoodaustralia.org.au/nqsplp/ ''National Quality Standard'' Professional Learning Program]

page.title: Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = NASPAA |motto = The Global Standard in Public Service Education |formation = 1970 |extinction = |type = NGO |status = |purpose = [[Educational accreditation]] |headquarters = Washington, DC |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.naspaa.org/ naspaa.org] |remarks = }} The '''Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration''' ('''NASPAA''') is a [[Washington, D.C.]]-based [[non-profit organization]]. It is an international association of [[public policy schools|public affairs schools]] (schools of [[public policy]] and [[public administration|administration]]) at [[University|universities]] in the [[United States]] and abroad. NASPAA is also the recognized by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA) as the accreditor of master's degree programs in public policy (MPP), public affairs (MPAff), and public administration (MPA).<ref>[http://www.chea.org/4DCGI/cms/review.html?Action=CMS_Document&DocID=200&MenuKey=main] CHAE. Retrieved 2017-12-15.</ref> Its stated mission is to "ensure excellence in education and training for public service and to promote the ideal of public service."<ref>[http://www.naspaa.org/about_naspaa/naspaa.asp "NASPAA Mission Statement."] NASPAA. Retrieved 2013-7-23.</ref>
==History and mission== Founded in 1970, NASPAA serves as a national and international resource for the promotion of excellence in education for the public service. Its institutional membership includes more than 280 university programs in the United States in public administration, policy, and management. NASPAA is also the accreditator of its member schools, seeking to promote the quality of education. It accomplishes its purposes through direct services to its member institutions and by: *Developing and administering appropriate standards for educational programs in public affairs through its Executive Council and its Commission on Peer Review and Accreditation; *Representing to governments and other institutions the objectives and needs of education for public affairs and administration; *Encouraging curriculum development and innovation and providing a forum for publication and discussion of education scholarship, practices, and issues; *Undertaking surveys that provide members and the public with information on key educational issues; *Meeting with employers to promote internship and employment for students and graduates; *Undertaking joint educational projects with practitioner professional organizations; and *Collaborating with institutes and schools of public administration in other countries through conferences, consortia, and joint projects.
NASPAA provides opportunities for international engagement for NASPAA members, placing a global emphasis on educational quality and quality assurance through a series of networked international initiatives, in particular the Network of Institutes and Schools of Public Administration in Central and Eastern Europe (NISPAcee), the Inter-American Network of Public Administration Education (INPAE), and the Georgian Institute of Public Affairs (GIPA). It is also involved locally, directing the Small Communities Outreach Project for Environmental Issues, which networks public affairs schools and local governments around environmental regulation policy issues, with support from the Environmental Protection Agency.
In 2013, NASPAA changed its name from the National Association of Schools of Public Affairs and Administration to the Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration to reflect its "growing international membership and disciplinary breadth."<ref>[http://www.naspaa.org/principals/news/name_announcement.pdf "NASPAA Announces New Name"] (Press Release). NASPAA. March 18, 2013. Retrieved 2013-7-23.</ref>
==''Journal of Public Affairs Education''== The '''''Journal of Public Affairs Education''''' ('''''JPAE''''') is a quarterly, [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]], [[academic journal]] of [[public administration]] education that is published by [[Taylor & Francis]] on behalf of the Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration.<ref>[https://patimes.org/protecting-and-promoting-jpaes-legacy/ "Protecting and Promoting JPAE's Legacy."] PA Times. Retrieved 2018-6-28.</ref><ref>{{book cite |last1=Liou |first1=Kuo-Tsai |date=2001 |title=Handbook of Public Management Practice and Reform |publisher=[[CRC Press]] |location=Boca Raton, FL}}</ref> The journal was established in 1995, and has been edited by [[Bruce D. McDonald, III]] ([[North Carolina State University]]) and William Hatcher ([[Augusta University]]) since 2017.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McDonald |first1=Bruce |last2=Hatcher |first2=William |title=From the Editors |journal=Journal of Public Affairs Education |volume=24 |issue=1 |date=2018 |pages=1–2 |doi=10.1080/15236803.2018.1431462}}</ref><ref name="naspaa1">[http://naspaa.org/initiatives/jpae/jpae.asp "Journal of Public Affairs Education,"] NASPAA. Retrieved 2018-6-28.</ref>
The ''Journal of Public Administration Education'' was founded in 1995 by [[H. George Frederickson]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Perry |first1=James |title=Reflections on the Journal of Public Affairs Education at 15: Changing NASPAA and the Field |journal=Journal of Public Affairs Education |volume=16 |issue=2 |date=2010 |pages=119–122 |doi=10.1080/15236803.2010.12001589}}</ref> Initially published in coordination with the [[American Society for Public Administration]]'s Section on Public Administration Education (SPAE), the [[National Association of Schools of Public Affairs and Administration]] (NASPAA) began discussions in 1996 of sponsoring the journal.<ref>{{cite book |last=Riccucci |first=Norma M. |date=2007 |chapter=Public Administration Pedagogy: What Is It? |pages=757-766 |editor1-last=Rabin |editor1-first=Jack |editor2-last=Hildreth |editor2-first=W. Bartley |editor3-last=Miller |editor3-first=Gerald J. |title=Handbook of Public Administration |edition=Third |publisher=[[Taylor and Francis]] |location=New York, NY}}</ref> In the fall of 1997, Frederickson transferred ownership of the journal to NASPAA. Under the new ownership, NASPAA elected to change the name of the journal to the ''Journal of Public Affairs Education'' to reflect the breadth of the NASPAA's mission and to increase the appeal of the journal. Despite the change in name ownership, the journal has continued to maintain a loose affiliation with SPAE.
Since taking ownership of the journal, ''JPAE'' has been self-published by NASPAA; however, in 2017 a publishing agreement was reached between NASPAA and [[Taylor & Francis]]. Since January 2018, Taylor & Francis has overseen the production and distribution of the journal.<ref name="naspaa1"/>
==Presidents== *2017-2018 - [[Jack W. Meek]], [[University of La Verne]] *2016-2017 - [[David Birdell]], [[Baruch College]] *2015-2016 - [[Michelle Piskulich]], [[Oakland University]] *2014-2015 - [[J. Edward Kellough]], [[University of Georgia]] *2013-2014 - [[Ethel Hill Williams]], [[University of Nebraska Omaha]] *2012-2013 - [[Jack Knott]], [[University of Southern California]] *2011-2012 - [[Nadia Rubaii]], [[Binghamton University]] *2010-2011 - [[Frances Berry]], [[Florida State University]] *2009-2010 - [[Jeffrey Raffel]], [[University of Delaware]] *2008-2009 - [[Marvin Mandell]], [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]] *2007-2008 - [[Kathleen Beatty]], [[University of Colorado Denver]] *2006-2007 - [[Kathryn Newcomer]], [[George Washington University]] *2005-2006 - [[Dan Mazmanian]], [[University of Southern California]] *2004-2005 - [[Eugenia Toma]], [[University of Kentucky]] *2003-2004 - [[B.J. Reed]], [[University of Nebraska at Omaha]] *2002-2003 - [[Jo Ivey Boufford]], [[New York University]] *2001-2002 - [[Carolyn Ban]], [[University of Pittsburgh]] *2000-2001 - [[Thomas P. Lauth]], [[University of Georgia]] *1999-2000 - [[Walter D. Broadnax]], [[American University]] *1998-1999 - [[Cornelius M. Kerwin]], [[American University]] *1997-1998 - [[Margaret Gordon (sociologist)|Margaret Gordon]], [[University of Washington]] *1996-1997 - [[Charles Wise]], [[Indiana University (Bloomington)]] *1995-1996 - [[Patricia W. Ingraham]], [[Syracuse University]] *1994-1995 - [[Davis B. Bobrow]], [[University of Pittsburgh]] *1993-1994 - [[H. Brinton Milward]], [[University of Arizona]] *1992-1993 - [[Naomi B. Lynn]], [[Sangamon State University]] *1991-1992 - [[Frank J. Thompson]], [[University at Albany, SUNY]] *1990-1991 - [[Adam Herbert|Adam W. Herbert]], [[University of North Florida]] *1989-1990 - [[Eleanor V. Laudicina]], [[Kean University|Kean College of New Jersey]] *1988-1989 - [[Max R. Sherman]], [[University of Texas at Austin]] *1987-1988 - [[Delmer D. Dunn]], [[University of Georgia]] *1986-1987 - [[Richard D. Heimovics]], [[University of Missouri–Kansas City]] *1985-1986 - [[Astrid E. Merget]], [[Ohio State University]] *1984-1985 - [[Robert E. Cleary]], [[American University]] *1983-1984 - [[Augustus Turnbull, III]], [[Florida State University]] *1982-1983 - [[Robert P. Biller]], [[University of Southern California]] *1981-1982 - [[Donald Stokes]], [[Princeton University]] *1980-1981 - [[Norman J. Johnson]], [[Carnegie Mellon University]] *1979-1980 - [[Clinton V. Oster]], [[Ohio State University]] *1978-1979 - [[James D. Kitchen]], [[San Diego State University]] *1977-1978 - [[C. Dwight Waldo]], [[Syracuse University]] *1976-1977 - [[Charles F. Bonser]], [[Indiana University]] *1975-1976 - [[Alan K. Campbell]], [[Syracuse University]] *1974-1975 - [[Thomas P. Murphy]], [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] *1973-1974 - [[Clyde J. Wingfield]], [[Baruch College]], [[City University of New York]] *1972-1973 - [[Morris W.H. Collins]], [[University of Georgia]] *1971-1972 - [[Laurin L. Henry]], [[University of Virginia]] *1970-1971 - [[Robert F. Wilcox]], [[San Diego State University]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''The Ohio Graduation Test (OGT)''' is the [[high school graduation examination]] given to [[Tenth grade#United_States|sophomores]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Ohio]]. Students must pass all five sections ([[Reading (process)|reading]], [[writing]], [[mathematics]], [[science]] and [[social studies]]) in order to graduate. Students have multiple chances to pass these sections and can still graduate without passing each using the alternative pathway. In 2009, the [[Ohio General Assembly|Ohio legislature]] passed an education reform bill eliminating the OGT in favor of a new assessment system. The development and transition of replacement began in 2014 and will end in 2022.
{{TOC limit|limit=15}}
==Test History and Development== ===History=== Prior to the OGT, passing the [[ninth grade proficiency test]] was required for graduation beginning with the class of 1994.<ref name="NGPT">{{cite web|url= http://education.ohio.gov/GD/DocumentManagement/DocumentDownload.aspx?DocumentID=21133 |title= Analysis of Ninth-Grade Proficiency Test Score, May 2006|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref> It had the same five subjects, apart from the social studies test was referred to as the [[Citizenship in the United States|citizenship]] test.
In 2001, the Ohio legislature directed the [[Ohio Department of Education]] (ODE) to develop the OGT based on the soon-to-be-adopted [[Ohio Academic Content Standards|academic content standards]].<ref name="SB1">{{cite web|url= http://archives.legislature.state.oh.us/bills.cfm?ID=124_SB_1 |title= Am. Sub. S.B. 1, 124th Ohio General Assembly|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref> The first official OGT was given in March 2005. It replaced the ninth grade proficiency test as a graduation requirement for the class of 2006. The last administration of the ninth grade proficiency test was in 2005.
===Development=== Questions are developed by ODE staff, sent through committees, and placed on exams before official inclusion on the OGT. First, the Content Advisory Committee runs the ODE developed question past parents and educators to see if it addresses the content. Second, the Fairness Sensitivity Review Committee helps ensure that questions are fair and do not put any student at a disadvantage because of a student’s moral values, social status, or religious beliefs. Third, the question is [[Pilot experiment|field tested]]. It is placed on an exam, but does not count towards the score of the student. Finally, the committees evaluate the performance data and decide if the question is to be used.<ref name="FAQ">{{cite web|url= http://www.ode.state.oh.us/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEDetail.aspx?page=3&TopicRelationID=216&ContentID=4904&Content=72934|title= Frequently Asked Questions about Ohio Graduation Tests|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref>
==Test Characteristics== ===Questions=== The OGT is made up of five tests: reading, writing, mathematics, science, and social studies. These sections match the core school subjects and fulfill the high school testing requirement in reading, mathematics, and science under the federal [[No Child Left Behind Act]].<ref name="NCLB">{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/admins/lead/account/saa.html#changes |title= No Child Left Behind – Testing Requirements|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref> Each of the five sections is formatted differently, but they each contain [[multiple choice]], [[Test_(student_assessment)#Free_response_items|short answer]], and [[Test_(student_assessment)#Free_response_items|extended response]] questions:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! <center>Subject<ref name="Blueprints">{{cite web|url=http://www.education.ohio.gov/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEDetail.aspx?page=3&TopicRelationID=216&ContentID=10825&Content=69259|title= OGT Blueprints|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref></center> ! <center>Multiple Choice</center> ! <center>Short Answer</center> ! <center>Extended Response</center> |- | Reading |<center>32</center> |<center>4</center> |<center>2</center> |- | Writing |<center>10</center> |<center>1</center> |<center>2</center> |- |Mathematics |<center>32</center> |<center>5</center> |<center>1</center> |- |Science |<center>32</center> |<center>4</center> |<center>2</center> |- |Social Studies |<center>32</center> |<center>4</center> |<center>2</center> |}total 38 questions
Each exam has approximately six extra questions that are being field tested for future OGT tests. Students are not penalized for incorrect answers on field tested questions. Students have up to two and a half hours to complete each section of the test.<ref name="FAQ" /> Typically, the tests are split up so that there is only one per day (for five days).
===Testing Dates=== The OGT is first given to students in the spring of their sophomore year. If they do not pass all five sections, they can continue to retake the exam. The OGT is administered in the fall (October), spring (March), and summer (June) each year.<ref name="Dates">{{cite web|url=http://www.ode.state.oh.us/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEPrimary.aspx?Page=2&TopicID=285&TopicRelationID=238|title= Testing Dates|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref> Not all schools offer the summer OGT, but students can be directed to one that does. Summer testing also requires a student to take at least 10 hours of preparatory programs beforehand.<ref name="SummerOGT">{{cite web|url=http://codes.ohio.gov/oac/3301-13-01|title=Ohio Administrative Code 3301-13-01(12)|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref> A typical student will have seven opportunities to pass the OGT before he or she is scheduled to graduate.
===Accommodations=== There are special accommodations of the OGT for students with special needs. These accommodations include tests with readers, in large print, and different languages like [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], and [[Somali language|Somali]].<ref name="Accommodations">{{cite web|url=http://www.education.ohio.gov/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEPrimary.aspx?Page=2&TopicID=1140&TopicRelationID=1139|title=Test Accommodations|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref> Students with an [[Individualized Education Program]] (IEP) may be exempted from the requirement to pass all sections of the OGT or may take another assessment if the plan allows.<ref name="FAQ" /> For students with significant disabilities, there is an [[No_Child_Left_Behind_Act#Variability_in_student_potential_and_100.25_compliance|alternate assessment]] that requires a collection of evidence that demonstrates knowledge appropriate for the student’s disabilities.<ref name="Alternative ">{{cite web|url=http://www.education.ohio.gov/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEDetail.aspx?page=3&TopicRelationID=229&ContentID=8695&Content=74519|title=Alternative Testing|accessdate= 2010-05-27}}</ref>
==Alternative Pathway== Passing all five of the OGT tests is required to earn an Ohio diploma for both public and private school students (excluding IEP issues).<ref name="GradReq">{{cite web|url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/3313.603|title=ORC§3313.603(F)(3)|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref><ref name="GradReqAlt ">{{cite web|url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/3313.612|title=ORC§3313.612|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> However, there is an exception for students who come very close. The alternative pathway lets student who meet seven specific requirements to graduate without passing all five tests. High school guidance counselors determine if students qualify for this option. A student qualifies for the alternative pathway if they:
# Pass all the tests but one, and earn at least a 390 on the failed test; # Have a 97% attendance rate, not including excused absences, for each of the last four years; # Have not been expelled in the past four years; # Have a GPA of 2.5 out of 4.0 in the subject area of the failed test; # Complete the high school curriculum requirements; # Have taken “[[Test preparation|intervention programs]]” to help their performance on the tests and have a 97% attendance rate, not including excused absence, in those programs; and # Receive a letter recommending graduation from each of the student’s high school teachers in the subject area of the failed OGT and the student's high school principal.<ref name="AP">{{cite web|url=http://education.ohio.gov/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEDetail.aspx?page=3&TopicRelationID=1702&ContentID=23705&Content=78114|title=Alternative Pathway for Eligibility for a Diploma - Overview|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref>
==Assessment Reforms== ===Ohio Reforms=== In 2009, the Ohio legislature passed an education reform bill that, among other things, called for the OGT to be replaced.<ref name="HB1">{{cite web|url=http://archives.legislature.state.oh.us/bills.cfm?ID=128_HB_1|title= Am. Sub. H.B. 1, 128th Ohio General Assembly|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> To receive a diploma, students will have to earn a certain composite score drawn from a new three part assessment system:
*A national standardized assessment (such as the [[ACT (test)|ACT]]) that assesses science, mathematics, and English language arts * A series of [[End of Course Test|end-of-course exams]] in English language arts, mathematics, science, and social studies *A [[senior project]] by a student or a group of students
The academic content standards and the model curriculum must be finished before the new assessment system can be developed to assure alignment. Work will begin on developing this new system in 2011.<ref name="HB1" /> There is no set date for the beginning of the new assessment system, but the 2013-2014 school year has been targeted.<ref name="HB1Dates">{{cite web|url=http://education.ohio.gov/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEDetail.aspx?page=3&TopicRelationID=1599&ContentID=62806&Content=85426|title=Education Reform Plan Information|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> The OGT will be phased out until 2022. <ref>{{cite web|title=Ohio Graduation Tests {{!}} ODE |url= http://education.ohio.gov/Topics/Testing/Ohio-Graduation-Test-OGT}}</ref>
===National Assessments=== Also in 2009, the federal [[Race to the Top]] $4.35 billion incentive program was announced.<ref name="RTTT">{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/programs/racetothetop-assessment/index.html|title=Race to the Top Assessment Program|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> It included up to $350 million for common assessment development.<ref name="RTTTFunding">{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/programs/racetothetop-assessment/funding.html|title=Race to the Top Assessment Program – Funding|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> Various consortia of states formed to compete for this grant. Ohio signed [[Memorandum of understanding|memorandums of understanding]] with two groups: Smarter Balance<ref name="SB">{{cite web|url=http://www.ode.state.or.us/wma/teachlearn/diploma/smarter-consortium-overview.pdf|title= Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> and Achieve.<ref name="Achieve">{{cite web|url=http://www.achieve.org/states-form-common-assessment-partnership|title=Achieve: States Form Common Assessment Partnership|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref> Whatever assessment systems these groups design may supersede the modified [[Ohio Achievement Assessment]] (grades 3-8), the three part assessment system, and the composite score passed by the Ohio legislature.
==Criticisms== The OGT receives many of the same [[Standardized_test#Disadvantages_and_criticism|criticisms]] as [[List of state achievement tests in the United States|other states’ standardized tests]]. Chief among them is that the assessments drive instruction, give students increased testing anxiety, and test preparations distract from classroom learning. The [[activist]], [[perennial candidate]], and former [[98 Degrees]] singer [[Justin Jeffre]] filed a formal letter of complaint asserting the OGT is "unfair" according to guidelines set forth in the Ohio Administrative Code.<ref name="JJ">{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/full/2283222?access_key=key-2aeh6dap6uf4nb7jn5ja|title=Justin Jeffre Complaint|accessdate = 2010-05-27}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of state achievement tests in the United States]] *[[Standards-based education]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.ode.state.oh.us/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEPrimary.aspx?Page=2&TopicRelationID=216|Ohio Department of Education] OGT section of the Ohio Department of Education Website *[http://portal.success-ode-state-oh-us.info/ Ohio’s Statewide Testing Porthole] Released OGT questions and practice questions *[http://education.ohio.gov/GD/Templates/Pages/ODE/ODEDetail.aspx?page=3&TopicRelationID=263&ContentID=832&Content=86310|OGT Results] Results from each administration of the OGT
[[Category:Education in Ohio]] [[Category:Standardized tests in the United States]] [[Category:Standards-based education]]

{{BLP sources|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Pierre Dulaine |image = File:Pierre_Dulaine.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = Dulaine in 2014 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1944|04|23}} |birth_place = Jaffa, Israel |death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> |death_place = |death_cause = |body_discovered = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = |nationality = |other_names = |citizenship = |education = |alma_mater = |occupation = |years_active = |employer = |known_for = Dancing Classrooms |home_town = |salary = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |children = |parents = |callsign = |website = http://www.dancingclassrooms.org/ |signature = |footnotes = |ethnicity = |networth = |spouse = |partner = |relations = }} '''Pierre Dulaine''' (born 23 April 1944)<ref name="BBC_RYG">{{cite web|title=Pierre Dulaine, dance instructor|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/raiseyourgame/sites/dedication/lessonsfromthelegends/pages/pierre_dulaine.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fwales%2Fraiseyourgame%2Fsites%2Fdedication%2Flessonsfromthelegends%2Fpages%2Fpierre_dulaine.shtml&date=2013-04-28|archivedate=2013-04-28}}</ref> is a dance instructor and dancer. He invented the Dulaine method of teaching dance. He also founded Dancing Classrooms, a Social and Emotional development program for 5th grade children that uses ballroom dancing as a vehicle to change the lives of the children and their families.
Notably, his early works with children was fictionalized in the film ''[[Take the Lead]]'', starring [[Antonio Banderas]] as Pierre Dulaine.
The documentary film ''[[Mad Hot Ballroom]]'' follows a Ballroom Dancing with Dancing Classrooms competition.
==Early life and education==
Pierre Dulaine was born in [[Jaffa]], Palestine in 1944.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pierre |first=Dulaine |title=About Us |url=http://www.dancingclassrooms.org/About/OurPeople/ |publisher=Pierre Dulaine |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502074945/http://dancingclassrooms.org/About/OurPeople/ |archivedate=2014-05-02 |df= }}</ref> His Irish father was serving with the [[British Army]] stationed in British Mandate Palestine; his mother is Palestinian. In 1948 his parents fled Israel. After eight months of moving several times, first in [[Cyprus]], then in [[England]] and [[Ireland]], Dulaine's family settled in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]]. In 1956, the [[Suez Crisis]] forced Dulaine's parents to flee the area, eventually resettling in [[Birmingham]], England.
==Career== Dulaine began his dancing career at the age of 14, and took his [[Associate Degree]] as a professional dancer when he was 18. He took three further majors exams aged 21 and became a full member of the [[Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing]].
In 1971 he worked as a solo dancer at the [[London Hippodrome]], as well as working at a [[nightclub]] called L'Hirondelle. Dulaine moved to [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] and worked for a year at the Nairobi Casino in cabaret with the Bluebell Troupe from Paris. After this, he became cruise director for a ship sailing from New York City to the Caribbean Islands. He then got a job at an [[Arthur Murray]] dance studio.
In January 1976, Dulaine became dance partners with [[Yvonne Marceau]], who had arrived at the dance studio in 1973. The pair studied in England with [[John DelRoy]], and won several awards. In 1984, they co-founded the [[American Ballroom Theater Company]] with Otto Cappel. The Company debuted at the Dance Theatre Workshop in October 1984, and toured widely in the late 1980s. From July 1989 to 1990, the pair appeared in [[Tommy Tune]]'s [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] show [[Grand Hotel (musical)|Grand Hotel]], finishing with a five-month run in the West End.
In 1994 Dulaine founded the Dancing Classrooms program for the [[New York City Department of Education]]. He also invented the "Dulaine Method" to encourage children to dance together. He later travelled to Northern Ireland to teach the same program. In 2011 Dulaine travelled to Jaffa, the city of his birth to teach the method and make the 2013 film ''Dancing in Jaffa''.
==See also== *[[List of teachers portrayed in films]] *''[[Take the Lead]]''
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.dancingclassrooms.org/ Pierre Dulaine Dance Club official website]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dulaine, Pierre}} [[Category:Dance teachers]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Modern dancers]] [[Category:Palestinian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:People from Jaffa]] [[Category:American ballroom dancers]]

page.title: Royal Air Force Centre for Air Power Studies

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} The '''Royal Air Force Centre for Air Power Studies''' ('''RAF CAPS''') is a [[Royal Air Force]] sponsored [[think tank]] which engages in the study of [[air power]].
The centre was launched on 23 August 2007 by [[Air Chief Marshal]] Sir [[Glenn Torpy]], [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]].<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/DefencePolicyAndBusiness/RafChiefUnveilsTheLatestWeaponInTheRafsInventory.htm Ministry of Defence | Defence News | Defence Policy and Business | RAF Chief unveils the latest weapon in the RAF's inventory<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Based at the [[Royal Air Force College]], this think tank and research centre claims to bring together [[academia]] with serving members of the RAF to analyse how air power has been used in the past and how best it might be used in a modern, complex world of increasing ambiguity.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> It aspires to act as the RAF’s centre for [[strategy|strategic]] and conceptual thinking about air power, to "encourage and promote the study of air power, particularly within the Service and academia, but also throughout the broader intellectual community (including the media and think-tanks)".<ref>[http://www.airpowerstudies.co.uk/index.htm CENTRE FOR AIR POWER STUDIES | Royal Air Force Centre for Air Power Studies (RAF CAPS)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The centre hosts a website, runs major conferences,<ref>[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/sspp/defence/news/news Forthcoming research conferences :News and events :King's College London<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> offers fellowships and, since 2008, publishes a journal called ''Air Power Review''.<ref>http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafcms/mediafiles/BC18F893_1143_EC82_2E16AC19F19FE2D2.pdf</ref><ref>[http://www.raf.mod.uk/downloads/airpowerreview.cfm RAF - Air Power Review<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Its board is headed by the [[Air Officer Commanding]] [[No. 22 Group RAF|No. 22 (Training) Group]]. Its staff consists of key members of the Royal Air Force, the [[Air Historical Branch|Air Historical Branch (RAF)]], and academics from [[King's College London]]'s Air Power Studies Division.<ref>[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/sspp/defence/apsd.html Air Power Studies Division :Defence Studies Department :King's College London<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://airminded.org/2007/11/14/raf-cranwell-and-a-conference/ Airminded · RAF Cranwell and a conference<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 2009 the RAF CAPS worked with a King's College team of air power experts under the direction of [[Joel Hayward|Dr Joel Hayward]] to develop the UK's first specialised [[master's degree]] in air power studies.<ref>http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafcms/mediafiles/E2264FCC_1143_EC82_2E9821F661F2FA58.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.airpowerstudies.co.uk/newmastersdegree.htm</ref>
The Chief of the Air Staff's Air Power Workshop, sometimes known merely as the CAS Workshop, is a small working group of senior scholars and other theorists convened by the [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of Air Staff]], the professional head of the [[Royal Air Force]]. Run by the successive Directors of Defence Studies (RAF), the Workshop develops and debates cutting-edge ideas on [[air power]] and sporadically produces books containing the findings.<ref>https://www.amazon.co.uk/Air-Power-21-Challenges-Century/dp/0117729604</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.airpowerstudies.co.uk/ Royal Air Force Centre for Air Power Studies]: official website.
[[Category:British defence policymaking]] [[Category:Foreign policy and strategy think tanks based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Military education and training in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Royal Air Force]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2012}} '''Savonlinna Music Academy''' ({{lang-fi|Savonlinnan musiikkiakatemia}}) is an association in [[Savonlinna]] (Finland) organizing international master classes in Savonlinna and abroad. On the master classes internationally renowned musicians teach young talented singers and instrumentalists in the field of [[opera]], [[lied]] and [[chamber music]].
Savonlinna Music Academy originated from Savonlinna Music Days organized by Finnish composer [[Yrjö Kilpinen]] in the 1950s. During the Music Days, teaching for young musicians was organized. The history of Savonlinna Music Academy thus goes back to times before [[Savonlinna Opera Festival]] made the small town internationally known. Over time the organization has changed, but the main principle of providing quality teaching has remained the same. Currently, master classes are organized within the framework Savonlinna Summer University (open university) teaching. Savonlinna Music Academy is directed by an artistic committee. The chair of the artistic committee is pianist [[Ralf Gothóni]]. The managing director of Savonlinna Music Academy Association is operationally responsible for activities.
Mainly master classes are organized in July when also Savonlinna Opera Festival takes place. For students this gives the opportunity to meet and hear many artists visiting Savonlinna for the festival. Concerts organized the Music Academy attract people coming to Savonlinna for opera and classical music. Instruction in singing comprises in addition to opera and lied also of teaching for vocalist-piano duos. In the chamber music master classes student and teachers make music together.
Similar teaching models are the Steans Institute of [[Ravinia Festival]] and the [[Mozarteum University of Salzburg|Mozarteum Orchestra]].<ref>Kamarimusiikkia Onnelisten Ateljeessa (concert programme) 2010. Savonlinna, Savonlinnasali</ref>
Instructors in lied have been [[Helmut Deutsch]], [[Irwin Cage]], [[Hartmut Höll]], [[Graham Johnson (musician)|Graham Johnson]] and [[Roger Vignoles]]. In opera [[Ilena Cotrubas]], [[Thomas Hemsley]], [[Dorothy Irving]], [[Jevgeni Nesterenko]], [[Peter Pears]], [[Mitsuko Shirai]] and [[Sarah Walker (mezzo-soprano)|Sarah Walker]] have been active. During the last years teachers mainly responsible have been [[Tom Krause]] and director [[Eija Tolpo]].
Savonlinna Music Academy has also made own productions such as [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]'s [[Cosi fan tutte]] and the 'Italienisches Liederbuch' of [[Hugo Wolf]] as an arrangement for chamber orchestra and two voices in 2005. In 2011 the Academy produced the comic opera [[Il matrimonio segreto]] by [[Domenico Cimarosa]]. The production also toured at Mustasaari Music Festival and in [[Detmold]]. In 2010 instruction in music technology and in 2011 in recording technology was started in cooperation with [[Sibelius Academy]] and [[Hochschule für Musik Detmold]].
The international activities of the Savonlinna Music Academy have included master classes in [[Cairo]], Egypt, where courses have been organized for Egyptian students in 2009 and 2010. Participating teachers in Cairo were pianist Ralf Gothoni, violist [[Teemu Kupiainen]], cellist professor [[Arto Noras]], director [[Eija Tolpo]] and pianist [[Jari Hiekkapelto]]. Egyptian musicians have also participated in master classes in Savonlinna.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== See also == * [http://www.savonlinnamusicacademy.com/ Savonlinna Music Academy] * [http://www.cimarosa.fi/ Savonlinna Music Academy production of Il matrimonio segreto.]
[[Category:Music education organizations]] [[Category:Educational organisations in Finland]] [[Category:Music schools in Finland]]

[[File:Sharon Draper (11515).jpg|thumb|Draper at [[BookExpo America]] in 2018]] '''Sharon Mills Draper''' (born August 21, 1948)[https://books.google.com/books?id=xrcY6VmaVCIC&pg=PA1 "Sharon M. Draper: Embracing Literacy"] by KaaVonia Hinton, Scarecrow Studies in Young Adult Literature, 31, [[Scarecrow Press]], 2008[http://authors.simonandschuster.com/Sharon-M-Draper/706340/revealed Simon and Shuster Authors A-Z: Sharon M. Draper] is an American children's writer and a professional educator, the 1997 [[National Teacher of the Year]]. She is a five-time winner of the [[Coretta Scott King Award]] for books about the African-American experience. She may be known best for the Hazelwood and Jericho series and for her historical novel ''[[Copper Sun]]''. Other books include ''[[Double Dutch (novel)|Double Dutch]]'', ''[[Out of My Mind (Draper novel)|Out of My Mind]]'' and ''[[Romiette and Julio]], and [[Stella by Starlight (novel)|Stella by Starlight]]''. Draper won the [[Margaret A. Edwards Award]] from [[American Library Association]] in 2015. The annual award recognizes one writer and a particular body of work for "significant and lasting contribution to young adult literature". The judges cited six novels that were published from 1994 to 2007: ''[[Tears of a Tiger]]'', ''[[Forged by Fire (novel)|Forged by Fire]]'', and ''[[Darkness Before Dawn]]'' (the Hazelwood trilogy); ''[[The Battle of Jericho (novel)|The Battle of Jericho]]'', ''[[November Blues]]'', and ''Copper Sun''. [http://www.ala.org/news/press-releases/2015/02/sharon-m-draper-wins-2015-edwards-award-tears-tiger-forged-fire-darkness-dawn "Sharon M. Draper wins 2015 Edwards Award for ''Tears of a Tiger'', ''Forged by Fire'', ''Darkness Before Dawn'', ''The Battle of Jericho'', ''November Blues'' and ''Copper Sun''"]. Press release February 2, 2015. American Library Association (ALA).
  [http://www.ala.org/yalsa/edwards-award "Edwards Award"]. Young Adult Library Services Association. ALA. Retrieved 2015-02-08. ==Personal life== Draper was born in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. She is graduate of [[Pepperdine University]]. She is an active participant in the activities of the YMCA of Cincinnati, a member of the National Council of Teachers of English, the International Reading Association, and [[Top Ladies of Distinction]]. Mrs. Draper travels extensively and has been a guest on television and radio programs throughout the country, discussing issues surrounding literature, reading, and education. She is an accomplished public speaker who addresses educational and literary groups of all ages, both nationally and internationally, with entertaining readings of her poetry and novels. She lives with her husband in Cincinnati, Ohio. Her daughter has [[Cerebral Palsy]], a disability which the main character in ''Out of My Mind'' also lives with. She only has one son, named Max, that is a freshman that attends a central Ohio school. {{cite web|title=Sharon Draper Author Page: Biography|url=http://sharondraper.com/biography.asp|publisher=2014 Sharon Draper|accessdate=20 December 2014}} ==Awards and honors== She is a [[Milken Family Foundation]] National Educator Award winner, and was the Duncanson Artist-in-Residence for the Taft Museum. She is a YWCA Career Woman of Achievement, and is the recipient of the Dean's Award from Howard University School of Education, the Pepperdine University Distinguished Alumnus Award, the Marva Collins Education Excellence Award, and the Governor's Educational Leadership Award. Last year she was named Ohio Pioneer in Education by the Ohio State Department of Education, received the Beacon of Light Humanitarian award, as well as the Doctor of Laws Degree from Pepperdine University. In 2011, she received the 33rd annual Jeremiah Ludington Memorial Award by the Educational and Media Association.[http://www.edupaperback.org/Resources/Documents/DraperEBMArelease.pdf "EBMA Names Sharon M. Draper Winner of the 33rd Annual Jeremiah Ludington Memorial Award"], Educational Book & Media Association, October 7, 2011. Retrieved August 17, 1016 She has been honored at the White House six times, and was chosen as one of only four authors in the country to speak at the [[National Book Festival]] Gala in Washington, D.C, and to represent the United States in Madrid at their Book Festival. Her book ''Copper Sun'' has been selected by the US State Department and the International Reading Association as the United States novel for the international reading project called Reading Across Continents. Students in the US, Nigeria, and Ghana are reading the book and sharing ideas. ''[[Tears of a Tiger]]'' has received numerous awards, including the [[American Library Ac.]]/[[Coretta Scott King Award]] for an outstanding new book, and was also honored as an [[ALA Best Books for Young Adults]]. It has been recognized as one of the best of the year by the Children's Book Council, the New York City Library, Bank Street College, and the National Council for Social Studies. It was also named as Best of the Best by [[Voice of Youth Advocates|VOYA]]. ''[[Forged by Fire (novel)|Forged by Fire]]'', the sequel to ''Tears of a Tiger'', was the 1997 [[Coretta Scott King Award]] winner, as well as the winner of the ALA Best Book Award and the Parent's Choice Award and the Indiana Young Hoosier Award. ''[[Darkness Before Dawn]]'', the third book in the trilogy, is an ALA Top Ten Quick Pick, and has received the [[Children's Choice Award]] from the International Reading Association and received the Buckeye Book Award for 2005, and was named an IRA Young Adult Choice for 2003. ''[[Romiette and Julio]]'' is also listed as an ALA Best Book and has been selected by the International Reading Association as a 2000 Notable Book for a Global Society, and by the New York Public Library in their Books for the Teen Age. ''[[Out of My Mind (Draper novel)|Out of My Mind]]'' was chosen the winner of the 2013 Sasquatch Reading Award by the readers of Washington State and the 2013 Bluestem Award by the third through fifth graders of Illinois. It won the 2013 [[California Young Reader Medal]] and the 2013 Nevada Young Readers Award{{cite web|url=http://www.wlma.org/sasquatch|title=Sasquatch Award|date=|publisher=Washington Library Media Association (wlma.org)|accessdate=2014-04-08}} {{page needed|date=August 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.islma.org/Bluestem.htm |title=The Bluestem Award: Illinois' Grades 3-5 Readers' Choice Award |publisher=Illinois School Library Media Association (islma.org) |date= |accessdate=2014-04-08}} 2013 Bluestem Award Winners (pdf).{{cite web |url=http://californiayoungreadermedal.org/winners.htm#2013 |title=Winners: 2013 Winners |publisher=California Young Reader Medal (californiayoungreadermedal.org) |accessdate=2014-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903092719/http://californiayoungreadermedal.org/winners.htm#2013 |archivedate=2013-09-03 |df= }}{{cite web| url=http://nevadalibraries.org/awards/nyra_winners.html |title=Nevada Young Readers Award: Past Winners |publisher=Nevada Library Association (nevadalibraries.org) |accessdate=2014-05-31}} Young Reader Category. ''[[Double Dutch (novel)|Double Dutch]]'' was honored as a Notable Social Studies Trade Book for Young People by the Children's Book Council as well as one of the top ten sports books for young adults for 2003 by the ALA, and Best of the Best for 2004, and received the [[Sunshine State Young Readers Award]] for 2006. ''[[The Battle of Jericho (novel)|The Battle of Jericho]]'' is the 2004 [[Coretta Scott King Award]], one of the New York Public Library's Book for the Teen Age, and is one of the 2005 Young Adult Choice Books named by the International Reading Association. ''Fire from the Rock'' has been selected by the NCSS-CBC Notable Social Studies Committee as a Notable Social Studies Trade Book for Young People for 2008 and is honored on the 2008 New York Public Library Best Books for the Teen Age. ''[[We Beat the Street]]'' is listed on the [[New York Times Bestseller List]] and is on VOYA's Non-Fiction Honor List for 2006 and is honored on the 2006 New York Public Library Best Books for the Teen Age. ''[[Copper Sun]]'' received the 2007 [[Coretta Scott King Award]], was named as one of the Top Ten Historical Fiction Books for Youth by Booklist was nominated for the 2007 NAACP Image Award for Literature, and received the Ohioana Award for Young Adult Literature. ''Copper Sun'' is also a CBC/NCSS Notable Social Studies Trade Book, received the Heartland Award for Excellence in YA Literature, was named as an IRA Notable Book for a Global Society and was named as Best Book of the Year by School Library Journal. ''Copper Sun'' is also listed on the [[New York Times Bestseller List]]. ''[[November Blues]]'' received the 2008 [[Coretta Scott King Award]] and is honored on the 2008 New York Public Library Best Books for the Teen Age. ''Sassy: Little Sister Is Not My Name!'' received the 2009 Parents Choice Award. ==Works== [[File:Sharon Draper.JPG|thumb|Draper in 2015]] {{Expand list|date=May 2013}} ===Hazelwood High Trilogy=== * ''[[Tears of a Tiger]]'' ([[Simon & Schuster]], 1994) {{ISBN|9780689318788}} * ''[[Forged by Fire (novel)|Forged by Fire]]'' (S&S, 1997) {{ISBN|9780689806995}} * ''[[Darkness Before Dawn]]'' (S&S, 2001) {{ISBN|9780689830808}} ===Jericho series=== * ''[[The Battle of Jericho (novel)|The Battle of Jericho]]'' (S&S, 2003) {{ISBN|9780756939267}} * ''[[November Blues]]'' (S&S, 2007) {{ISBN|9781416906988}} * ''[[Just Another Hero]]'' (S&S, 2009) {{ISBN|9781416995210}} ===Sassy series=== # ''Sassy: Little Sister Is Not My Name'' ([[Scholastic Press]], 2009) # ''Sassy: The Birthday Storm'' (Scholastic, 2009) # ''Sassy: The Silver Secret'' (Scholastic, 2010) # ''Sassy: The Dazzle Disaster Dinner Party'' (Scholastic, 2010) ===Ziggy and the Black Dinosaurs series=== # ''The Buried Bones Mystery'' (S&S, 1994) # ''Lost in the Tunnel of Time'' (S&S, 1996) # ''Shadows of Caesar's Creek'' (S&S, 1997) # ''The Space Mission Adventure'' (S&S, 2006) # ''The Backyard Animal Show'' (S&S, 2006) # ''Stars and Sparks on Stage'' (S&S, 2007) ===Standalone novels=== * ''[[Romiette and Julio]]'' (S&S, 1999) {{ISBN|9781442428850}} * ''[[Double Dutch (novel)|Double Dutch]]'' (S&S, 2002) * ''[[Copper Sun]]'' (S&S, 2006) {{ISBN|9780689821813}} * ''Fire from the Rock'' ([[Dutton Children's Books]], 2007) * ''[[Out of My Mind (Draper novel)|Out of My Mind]]'' (S&S, 2010) {{ISBN|9781416971719}} * ''Panic'' (S&S Atheneum Books, 2013) {{ISBN|9781442408982}} * ''Stella by Starlight'' ([[Atheneum Books]], January 2015) {{ISBN|9781442494992}} ===Non-fiction=== * ''Teaching from the Heart: reflections, encouragement, and inspiration'' (Portsmouth, NH: [[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann]], 2000), {{LCCN|99039534}} * ''Not Quite Burned Out, But Crispy around the Edges: inspiration, laughter, and encouragement for teachers'' (Heinemann, 2001), {{LCCN|2001020423}} * ''[[We Beat the Street]]'' (Dutton, 2005) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website }} * [http://www.orrt.org/draper/ Draper] at Ohio Reading Road Trip * {{LCAuth|n94024391|Sharon M. {{UDP|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox organization | logo = Logo_for_Snapask.png | formation = 2015 | type = Private | headquarters = Hong Kong, China | services = Education-Technology | name = Snapask | website = https://www.snapask.com | founder = Timothy Yu }}
'''Snapask''' is a [[Hong Kong]]-based [[Educational technology|education technology]] company that offers tutoring services to the students based in [[Hong Kong]], [[Singapore]], [[Thailand]], [[Korea]], [[Indonesia]], [[Japan]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Taiwan]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-36461191|title=Tutors become part of the app culture|last=Jackson|first=Tom|date=2016-06-08|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/snapask-homework-education-app-startup|title=Tech in Asia - Connecting Asia's startup ecosystem|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref> In 2016, Snapask was awarded for the best team at the France Singapore ICT Awards 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.youbuyfrance.com/sg/Posts-13050-france-singapore-ict-awards-2016|title=France Singapore ICT Awards 2016|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref>
== Overview == Snapask was founded by Timothy Yu<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carolinehoward/2016/02/24/the-leading-millennial-consumer-tech-founders-in-asia/#5a0bec241fc2|title=The Leading Millennial Consumer Tech Founders In Asia|last=Howard|first=Caroline|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref> in January 2015.<ref name=":1" /> With its headquarters in Hong Kong, it expanded to Taiwan and [[Singapore]] in the year 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.asianentrepreneur.org/timothy-yu-founder-of-snapask/|title=Timothy Yu, Founder of Snapask - Asian Entrepreneur|last=Laing|first=Callum|date=2015-06-12|work=Asian Entrepreneur|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://yp.scmp.com/entertainment/tech-and-games/article/94770/snapask-puts-private-tutors-just-click-away|title=SnapAsk puts private tutors just a click away|work=Young Post {{!}} South China Morning Post|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>
In 2016, January, Snapask launched a new version Snapask 3.0, that was said to have better optimization with respect to the student-tutor matching mechanism to induce faster responses. According to Yu, this version included [[Machine learning algorithm|machine-learning algorithm]] to understand students’ study pattern.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hkmb.hktdc.com/en/1X0A4WVH/venture-hong-kong/Snappy-Answers|title=Snappy Answers {{!}} Hong Kong Means Business|work=Hong Kong Means Business|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>
In March 2016, Snapask became one of the companies to use [[Watson (computer)|Watson]], a question answering (QA) computing system built by IBM, which involves advanced [[natural language processing]], [[automated reasoning]], [[information retrieval]] and [[Knowledge representation and reasoning|knowledge representation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mis-asia.com/tech/applications/ibm-encourages-innovation-across-apac/|title=IBM encourages innovation across APAC|website=www.mis-asia.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www-07.ibm.com/ibm/my/media/news/2016-03-11-sg1.html|title=IBM - ASEAN News Room - News - ASEAN|date=|website=www-07.ibm.com|language=en-MY|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/ibm-watson-new-venture-challenge-winning-startups|title=Tech in Asia - Connecting Asia's startup ecosystem|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref>
In 2017 January, Snapask launched Snapask 4.0, which included concept-based quizzes, as an advanced feature.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/hong-kong-online-tutoring-platform-snapask-raises-us5m-targets-4-million-users-southeast-asia-20170601/|title=Hong Kong online tutoring platform Snapask raises US$5M, targets 4 million users in Southeast Asia|work=e27|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
As of June 2017, Snapask has a userbase of more than 300,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.xfer.tk/homework-app-snapask-preps-indonesia-launch-after-investment/|title=Homework app Snapask preps Indonesia launch after investment|last=|first=|date=2017-06-13|work=News Asia|access-date=2017-09-29|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
Snapask was one among the top 20 finalists at the 2017 EdTechXGlobal All Star Growth Awards.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
== Technology == Snapask<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rebeccafannin/2016/03/20/taiwan-how-long-will-fear-of-failure-outweigh-urge-to-start-up/#5f9ef03b7591|title=Taiwan: How Long Will Fear Of Failure Outweigh Urge To Start Up?|last=Fannin|first=Rebecca|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}}</ref> works as a mobile crowdsourcing platform that involves [[artificial intelligence]] and allows students to connect to tutors and receive instant one-on-one academic support.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/news/business/corporate/30316863|title=HK-based edtech start-up raises funds for expansion into SE Asia - The Nation|work=The Nation|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/hong-kong-online-tutoring-platform-snapask-raises-us5m-targets-4-million-users-southeast-asia-20170601/|title=Hong Kong online tutoring platform Snapask raises US$5M, targets 4 million users in Southeast Asia|work=e27|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref> This app is said to address the questions and problems asked by its users<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/article/1963657/tech-start-ups-focus-hong-kongs-thriving-education-sector|title=Tech start-ups focus on Hong Kong’s thriving education sector|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}}</ref> within 15 seconds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cb.cityu.edu.hk/CityBusinessMagazine/2016-autumn/en/cyberport-search-for-the-next-gogovan|title=Cyberport search for the next GoGoVan|last=CityU|first=College of Business,|work=City Business Magazine, College of Business, City University of Hong Kong|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref> Students are asked to take a picture of their queries and submit it to the platform; these questions are then, addressed by the tutors at Snapask.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/education/apps-help-with-homework-or-tuition|title=Apps help with homework or tuition|last=hermes|date=2016-12-05|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>
== References == <references />
